texts.shortText:
Small, bright orange-red species with bushy fern-like appearance. Main axes flattened and minutely, but not obviously, separated into segments. Side branches emerge alternately and then re-branch at least twice, the terminal branches tapering to pointed tips. Whole plant forms a series of neat, flattened, fern-like blades.

Several similar species are known from the region, but this specimen if difficult to match exactly to any of these, although it seems closest in its branching pattern to P. stangeri or P. complanate. We thus treat this as a genetic level entry and do not commit to a species identification.

Global: As this is a generic entry, distribution cannot be given.

Local/Regional: Several species of this genus reported from different parts of the coast.
Distinctive and attractive little species with a neat, symmetrical appearance. Has been observed several times on rock pools in the lower intertidal in Table Bay, often attached to mussels.
In this genus tetrasporangia are borne one per segment in the distal parts of the thallus.

There are several species of this genus in the region. Of these P. spinifera has round, not flattened axes, P stegengae wider, more flattened ones, while P. cloiophylla is more finely branched and dark-red in colour. This species appears closest to P. stangeri or P. complanata, but neither of these have previously been reported from the South African west coast, the first being known from False Bay eastwards and the second from Europe southwards to Namibia, but not from South Africa itself.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 410).

Savoie, AM & Saunders, GW (2016). A molecular phylogenetic and DNA barcode assessment of the tribe Pterosiphonieae (Ceramiales, Rhodophyta) emphasizing the Northeast Pacific. Botany, 94(10), 917-939.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 559).
